questions.text: A 7-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents 30 minutes after she stopped breathing and “turned blue” during her nap. Her father mentions that she felt “floppy” when he tried to wake her. Thirty seconds later, the patient spontaneously started crying, and her skin color returned to normal. She was born at 35 weeks following an uncomplicated pregnancy and spontaneous vaginal delivery. She was exclusively breastfed and has recently been introduced to solid foods. She has no history of similar episodes and is otherwise healthy. Vaccinations are up-to-date. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight and at the 75th percentile for head circumference. Development is appropriate for age. She is alert and appears well. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 132/min, and respirations are 38/min. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. ECG shows a regular sinus rhythm and no acute abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pulse oximetry measures oxygen saturation and should be used to evaluate hypoxemia in infants with cyanosis. Although brief monitoring (i.e., 1–4 hours) with pulse oximetry is optional for low-risk BRUE, inpatient monitoring for 24 hours is not recommended.

B) INCORRECT:

Nocturnal polysomnography is used to diagnose obstructive sleep apnea, central sleep apnea, and other forms of sleep-disordered breathing. Although this infant presents with an apneic episode, her symptoms fulfill the diagnostic criteria for low-risk BRUE, for which nocturnal polysomnography is not recommended.

C) CORRECT:

A BRUE is considered low risk when all of the following criteria are met: age > 60 days, gestational age at birth ≥ 32 weeks or corrected gestational age ≥ 45 weeks, the event lasts < 1 minute, first BRUE, CPR by a trained medical provider was not required, no concerning signs on physical examination (e.g., bruising, choking, coughing), and no concerning history (e.g., apneas, feeding problems). No further evaluation is warranted for patients with a low-risk BRUE. Caregivers should be provided with reassurance, education, and CPR training. BRUE is a diagnosis of exclusion; an underlying condition is the actual cause of the episode in about half of infants who present with features of BRUE. Patients who do not meet all of the criteria for low-risk BRUE are considered high risk and should be evaluated for underlying causes. When no cause can be established, prolonged hospital admission for monitoring may be required.

D) INCORRECT:

Echocardiography is used to evaluate for congenital heart disease, which is a potential cause of cyanosis in patients with a right-to-left shunt. This patient's cardiovascular examination is normal, and echocardiography is not recommended for the workup of low-risk BRUE. Electrocardiogram is optional to screen for channelopathies (e.g., long QT syndrome) in individuals with BRUE.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood gas analysis is performed in infants to screen for inborn errors of metabolism, which can manifest with lethargy. Inborn errors of metabolism typically appear with additional signs, such as vomiting and developmental delays, which are not found here. Blood gas analysis is not required for low-risk BRUE.
questions.hint: A sudden, brief (< 1 minute), and resolved episode involving cyanosis and hypotonia without apparent cause in a child < 1 year is consistent with a brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE)

questions.text:
A full-term 9-week-old female infant is brought into the emergency department by her parents after they saw her stop breathing and become stiff for about 10 seconds while she was sleeping. They promptly woke her during the episode, at which point she cried and then calmed with swaddling and fell back to sleep. The episode did not occur immediately after a feeding, and the infant did not appear to change color during the event. Her parents report that she has been nursing well, generally every 3 hours, with a normal number of stools and wet diapers. She has not had any recent fevers or sick contacts.
She has a temperature of 36.8°C, a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 38 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 99% while breathing ambient air. She awakens and squirms during the examination and produces a social smile. Her fontanelle is open and flat, and she has no dysmorphic facial features. Her pupils are equal and reactive, and she has an intact palate. She has a regular heart rate with regular rhythm and no murmur. Her femoral pulses are 2+, her distal extremities are warm, and her capillary refill rate is <2 seconds. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. Her abdomen is soft and nondistended with positive bowel sounds, and she has no hepatosplenomegaly. She has no rashes or lesions. Her tone is appropriate. After the examination, she nurses.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Admit the patient for telemetry monitoring overnight
Offer the parents education and cardiopulmonary-resuscitation training, and discharge the patient to home
Perform an evaluation for sepsis, including blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid studies

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If an infant with a BRUE does not meet low-risk criteria or the history and physical examination reveal a potential explanation for the event, then additional monitoring and diagnostic studies are warranted. These may include cardiac monitoring on telemetry to evaluate for congenital heart disease and arrhythmias. Infants who meet criteria for a low-risk BRUE (as in this case) do not require additional evaluation and can be safely discharged to home.

B) CORRECT:

This episode meets all the criteria for a brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE) in that it:

• Occurred in a child <1 year of age
• Involved at least one of the following:
• Cyanosis or pallor
• Absent, decreased, or irregular breathing
• Marked change in tone (hyper- or hypotonia)
• Altered level of responsiveness
• Has since resolved (with normal vital signs and normal examination findings)
• Remains unexplained after a thorough history and physical examination

The term BRUE was introduced in 2016 as a substitute for “apparent life-threatening event” (ALTE) in part because many of these events are not life-threatening and can likely be managed safely without extensive diagnostic evaluation. Several criteria are used to identify a lower-risk BRUE:

• The patient was older than 60 days at the time of the episode
• The patient was born at ≥32 weeks’ gestation with a postconceptional age ≥45 weeks
• Cardiopulmonary resuscitation was not administered by a trained medical provider during the episode
• The episode was characterized by the observer(s) as brief (lasting <1 minute)
• The patient has no prior BRUEs

Infants who meet criteria for a low-risk BRUE (as in this case) do not require additional evaluation and can be safely discharged to home. Those who have been exposed to pertussis may undergo pertussis testing, and some low-risk infants may undergo electrocardiography — for example, if they have a family history of arrhythmias or unexpected early cardiac death or if the mother has systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) or Sjögren syndrome. Women with SLE or Sjögren syndrome can produce anti-SSA/Ro antibodies, which can cause congenital heart block in infants. This infant is not known to have any indications to warrant such testing.

If an infant with a BRUE does not meet low-risk criteria or the history and physical examination reveal a potential explanation for the event, then additional monitoring and diagnostic studies are warranted. These may include full evaluation for sepsis with blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures; a chest radiograph; cardiac monitoring on telemetry to evaluate for congenital heart disease and arrhythmias; and electroencephalography to evaluate for seizures.

Key learning point: A single brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE) that occurs in a full-term 9-week-old infant, lasts less than one minute, and does not require cardiopulmonary resuscitation is considered a low-risk event that does not require extensive evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

If an infant with a BRUE does not meet low-risk criteria or the history and physical examination reveal a potential explanation for the event, then additional monitoring and diagnostic studies are warranted. These may include full evaluation for sepsis with blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid cultures. Infants who meet criteria for a low-risk BRUE (as in this case) do not require additional evaluation and can be safely discharged to home.

D) INCORRECT:

If an infant with a BRUE does not meet low-risk criteria or the history and physical examination reveal a potential explanation for the event, then additional monitoring and diagnostic studies are warranted. These may include a chest radiograph. Infants who meet criteria for a low-risk BRUE (as in this case) do not require additional evaluation and can be safely discharged to home.

E) INCORRECT:

If an infant with a BRUE does not meet low-risk criteria or the history and physical examination reveal a potential explanation for the event, then additional monitoring and diagnostic studies are warranted. These may include electroencephalography to evaluate for seizures. Infants who meet criteria for a low-risk BRUE (as in this case) do not require additional evaluation and can be safely discharged to home.

questions.text:
A 2-month-old infant is brought to the office after two episodes of suddenly stopping breathing and appearing pale and blue around the lips immediately following feeding. Each time, the color returned within a few seconds, and the child quickly returned to a normal state. Physical examination is normal, and the infant’s growth and developmental milestones are appropriate.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Congenital heart disease can cause cyanotic episodes due to structural anomalies. However, it usually presents with additional findings like a heart murmur, persistent hypoxemia, or poor growth, which are absent here. The normal examination and self-resolving episodes, especially related to feeding, argue against a structural cardiac issue.

B) INCORRECT:

Infantile spasms are an epileptic syndrome in infants aged 3 to 8 months, characterized by clusters of brief, symmetric contractions and an abnormal electroencephalogram (EEG). The described episodes of apnea and cyanosis following feeding in a 2-month-old, with normal examination findings, do not align with epileptic events. The absence of abnormal posturing, seizure clusters, or developmental regression further argues against infantile spasms.

C) INCORRECT:

Pertussis, caused by Bordetella pertussis, presents with paroxysmal coughing and sometimes apnea in infants. However, the episodes here are linked to feeding, not typical for pertussis. The brief episode duration and absence of persistent cough or systemic symptoms argue against an infectious cause. Normal examination and development further decrease the likelihood of pertussis.

D) CORRECT:

A Brief Resolved Unexplained Event (BRUE) is characterized by a sudden, brief episode of altered breathing, color, muscle tone, or responsiveness in an infant under one year of age, resolving spontaneously. In this case, the 2-month-old experienced apnea and perioral cyanosis after feeding, with rapid recovery and normal examination findings. The absence of ongoing symptoms or abnormal findings supports a low-risk BRUE diagnosis, which is self-limited and not indicative of underlying pathology when appropriately evaluated. This diagnosis relies on the brief event duration, complete return to baseline, and lack of evidence for serious conditions.

Key learning point: In infants, episodes of apnea and cyanosis occurring after feeding, with normal examination and growth, are suggestive of an acute life-threatening event (ALTE), now referred to as a brief resolved unexplained event (BRUE), often related to gastroesophageal reflux.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant presents to the emergency department after the parents witnessed a 45-second episode of facial pallor and decreased muscle tone while feeding. The infant was born at 33 weeks gestational age and is now at 36 weeks postconceptional age. The parents report no previous similar episodes and state they did not perform CPR, though the episode was concerning enough that they called 911. On examination, the infant appears well with normal vital signs, clear lungs, regular heart rhythm, and no dysmorphic features. The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discharge home with pediatric follow-up and CPR training for parents
Obtain head CT and chest radiograph
Transfer to pediatric intensive care unit for immediate stabilization

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – This high-risk BRUE requires admission for continuous pulse oximetry and comprehensive evaluation.

B) INCORRECT:

Discharge is not appropriate for this high-risk BRUE patient due to young age and prematurity.

C) INCORRECT:

Extended observation alone is insufficient for high-risk BRUE; this patient needs admission and diagnostic evaluation.

D) INCORRECT:

Head CT and chest X-ray are not routinely indicated for evaluation of high-risk BRUE unless child maltreatment is suspected.

E) INCORRECT:

Transfer to intensive care is not indicated for a stable infant with resolved symptoms. High-risk BRUE patients require admission to a monitored setting but do not automatically need intensive care unless they have ongoing instability or concerning findings.

questions.text: A previously healthy 4-month-old infant is brought to the emergency department after a witnessed 30-second episode where the baby became pale, had irregular breathing, and briefly lost muscle tone while awake. The episode resolved spontaneously without intervention. The infant was born at 38 weeks gestation with no complications. Vital signs are stable, physical examination is normal, and the patient appears well. This is the infant's first such episode. What is the most appropriate disposition for this patient?

choices.text: Continuous pulse oximetry monitoring for 12 hours
Discharge home with pediatric cardiology follow-up within 48 hours
Admit for observation and comprehensive diagnostic workup
Discharge home with primary care follow-up and caregiver education
Discharge home with 24-hour Holter monitor and neurology follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Continuous pulse oximetry monitoring for 12 hours is not indicated for low-risk BRUE.

B) INCORRECT:

While cardiology consultation may be considered in some cases, immediate subspecialty follow-up is not routinely required for low-risk BRUE. Primary care follow-up is more appropriate for initial management.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient meets low-risk BRUE criteria and does not require admission or comprehensive diagnostic workup.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient meets all low-risk BRUE criteria and can be considered for outpatient management. Follow-up with a primary care physician should be arranged, and caregivers should receive education on BRUE and SIDS prevention.

E) INCORRECT:

Home cardiorespiratory monitoring is not recommended for low-risk BRUE. Additionally, neurology consultation is not indicated for patients meeting low-risk criteria.
